abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Grain Storage Project
            for Pakistan was successful. Most of the physical targets
            were achieved, the impact of the project has been
            significant, sustainability is likely under certain
            conditions, and both the Borrower and the Bank acted
            satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the Bank should examine beforehand whether
            the action proposed to be taken to substitute for
            non-compliance of a covenant would fully serve the desired
            purpose. Second, it should spell out clearly and give more
            prominence at appraisal to the "software"
            component of a project. Third, the Bank needs to ensure a
            prior commitment of the government to sustain the
            institutional capability developed after the expiry of the
            project period. Fourth, it should assess the social and
            legal framework in which the project is to be executed
            before incorporating under the project proposals which a
            priori would have little meaning. Lastly, the Government of
            Pakistan should clearly understand a project's short
            and long term objectives as well as its financial
            implications. It should also understand the need for a total
            commitment to its successful undertaking.
